Topic.Title: Finally A very good reason for Apple to consider Nvidia

Message.Msg: If you haven't seen Jen Hsun's interview by Charlie Rose - oh maybe a couple of years ago - it may well be worth your time to view it. Apparently, by his own account, JH went to a "reform school" for troubled boys somewhere in the South. He was sent there not because anything he did or didn't do, but rather due to the fact that his 1st generation immigrant uncle didn't know anything better - he heard that the school offered good disciplines and was free. It wasn't Philips Academy or Andover prep schools, but JH likely derived some life-long benefits from this experience. He is tough, bold, and a true survivor. The Stanford education only reinforce these qualities.

Topic.Title: Finally A very good reason for Apple to consider Nvidia

Message.Msg: Ibx is right about JH not selling out unless he's at the helm. That is a very high bar to cross. On the other hand - there would be a price where everything is possible - that's life - it would be some astronomical number however. JH and team certainly believe they can take the company to $25ps - so that would be a starting point for any discussion that would preclude him running a combined company. It would be more interesting to see Nvidia morph into a system company like Apple /Samsung/HP. They are already half way there. Somebody mentioned Nvidia customizing chips for them - that certainly is a possibility - Apple had a lot of experience with that kind of relationship in the past. Apple right now is clearly behind - their GPU performance superiority in the past was achieved simply by using a large off the shelf GPU area - nothing elegant about it - such brute force approach has severe limitations in terms of power, cost and manufacturability - all of which is coming to a head at Samsung fabs.

Message.Title: For Those Of You That Think Jensen Has Not Changed
Message.Msg: 20 year anniversary coming up. 4 years of fighting for his companies existence. Lived through a near death experience from the bad packaged die problem in 2008 costing $800M along with Intel lawsuits, coming after being on top of the world in 2007. Now donating $20M to Stanford for building naming rights in 2012 and building the typical ostentatious silicon valley headquarter building in 2013-2014. But more importantly compare these two quotes only 3 months apart. From 2Q 2012 earnings transcript Analyst And, Jen-Hsun, one more. You guys have a lot of cash. Got any plans for that cash? Jen-Hsun Huang The only plans that we have ready to announce right now is to make a lot more cash. From 3Q 2012 earnings transcript "We are committed to return cash to our shareholders and made this decision based on our strong cash position and the high confidence we have in our business to continue generating future cash." OK - A sign of maturity? After all Jensen is around 50 now. Plus he knows his baby(Nvidia) will live. But their are a lot of employees that have a lot of options that want the stock to rise or they just might seak greener pastures. The best way to retain your employees in the semiconductor business is to afford them a vision of that eventual payout on options. If you don't, the best will leave no matter what you do. JMHO

Topic.Title: For Those Of You That Think Jensen Has Not Changed

Message.Msg: Who knows....but Nvidia was absolutely the last Tech company I ever expected to start a dividend and buyback shares. But here we are and they are doing it and it's good for shareholders and it's good for the employees with all those options. The building of a new headquarters will make top management very happy and the middle and lower ranks will have more space which is good. But you know they are checking their company options and wondering is this what will let me hold my head up in the Valley. Most famous quote from Silicon Valley in the go go years was "I want it all, and I want it now."

Topic.Title: GeekBench - Tegra 4 Scores as High as Mobile I5 Ivy Bridge Intel Processor - Must See

Message.Msg: Intel have never used this benchmark. It is also an uncontrolled user benchmark run over the internet so there is no real standardization between different tests and you can get different results purely depending what's running on your machine (e.g. safe mode will increase your score). Also you can view i5 results as high as 12,157 and i3 results as high as 8337 so I don't think anybody in Intel will be losing any sleep over this just they like didn't when Nvidia erroneously said Tegra 3 was faster than Core 2 Duo ;-). A15 is not in the same performance class as a Core processor unless that Core processor is purposely slowed down like in a 0.8-1.0 GHz Celeron and even then only in some benchmarks can it hang with it. Sorry Tegra 4 will not be a PC replacement as Intel will just use an appropriate sku to neutralize it like it does with AMD already, the process is called Celeronization ;-). browserDOTprimatelabsDOTcom/geekbench2/1706863 browserDOTprimatelabsDOTcom/geekbench2/1703318

Topic.Title: Samsung Exynos 5 Octa Antutu score: 24249

Message.Msg: T4 was not tested in a production tablet that has power management. It uses the same generic A15 core as the Exynos 5 Octa and there is no reason to believe these scores will be duplicated in a production tablet as they will not have 4 cores running at 1.9 GHz as this test device did. What is being shown here in reality is what the Project Shield Controller is capable of as it has a meaty enough heatsink and fan not to be clock throttled.

Topic.Title: Finally A very good reason for Apple to consider Nvidia

Message.Msg: "Sorry but nobody needs Nvidia as anybody can do what Nvidia is doing and use generic ARM cores." that's what brcm said in their investor's day last nov. The question they asked themselves was how could anybody differentiate and add values. For brcm, that was using single chip fully integrated solutions to attack the bulk of the market. brcm could not care less about the top of the market where #1 & #2 will use their own chip sets, #3 is cheap only, and #4 is into spreading the wealth. There is no money to be made, and tons of money to be lost, doing it the way nvda is doing. nvda and nvda longs here have not accepted that above fact about the market segment that they are chasing. nvda needs LTE a whole lot less than they need 3G and even 2G for the next two years.

Topic.Title: The 200dma is like a wall of steel...

Message.Msg: While I don't really put much credence in technical analysis, the 200DMA certainly seems to be a major issue in that work. So, it stands to reason that it would be a serious battle to regain it, or defend it, depending on which way the stock is moving. Regaining it "says" that the stock is back in a Bull Market, and after 2 years of relatively few closes above it, and none in the last 5 months, I think that's why this is happening. That said, it will be interesting to see if some of the larger shareholders finally engender a late day push to clear it and close there. While one day's close over it won't be that meaningful, it WILL show up as a "weekly close" over it, and that is more important in that work than a "daily close". And, guys that now do what I used to do, meaning that they will get their "charts" delivered, Saturday morning, and they will be looking for JUST this kind of "signal" to plan their trades for next week. With volume this quiet, today, it will take at least 3-4mm more shares towards the last 1/2 hour, I would think. We're at 7.55mm at 3:18. Let's see what they decide to do. As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. Best, Max

Message.Msg: No, mobile Celerons range from $65 to $134 and those are launch prices so all would be less now. If you want I can dig out Intel's current list pricing if you want. Fundamentally a Celeron is just a fused off or die defective Core, there is no real cost difference to the die and Intel can just shift a Core type sku into the Celeron bracket if it needs more firepower, the die cost to itself is negligible. It is a big myth that Intel needs to sell its chips at $300-400 to make a profit. arkDOTintelDOTcom/products/family/43401

Topic.Title: GeekBench - Tegra 4 Scores as High as Mobile I5 Ivy Bridge Intel Processor - Must See

Message.Msg: 'With $25 chips equaling their lowest power 2nd highest performing mobile chip that sells for some astronomical price.' You are wrong, there is no equaling. Core is 2-4 times faster than an A15 per core. You also have a problem listening to what I am actually saying, Intel can vary the performance/price ratio of its chips to beat any ARM competition and still leave more expensive higher performer chips above it, its margin of superiority is that high. 'How long do you think they will be able to keep those fabs open while running at 60% of capacity? ' Intel's Fabs will be working at much higher capacity later this year purely by the fact that they are converting 22nm to 14nm. Intel can easily change the mix of its Fabs from production to next generation development to change its loading. Also where are these production Tegra 4s ? Haswell will arrive before Tegra 4 does in a production mobile device and that's going to do a lot more damage to Nvidia than Tegra 4 will do to Intel which is nothing btw. Tegra 4's effect on Intel will be like a cruiser's 8" shell bouncing harmlessly off a battleship's 15" armor. In fact the next generation quad-core Atom Bay Trail will handle Tegra 4 easily enough by itself at the end of the year.

Message.Msg: Getanid, I disagree about now is the time to go long Intel. IMHO it's too early. We have the passing of the baton on the CEO, Analysts freaking out about the capex rise and generally pooh pawing the microprocessor market for standard PCs. In the past Intel handled this kinda funk by either 1 of 2 actions: 1) Fab Layoffs or 2) Capex cut Generally right at the beginning of the 2nd half of the year when forecasted growth doesn't pick up at near the speed they said. In the past either of the two actions placated the market. Generally right when the dividend yield nears 5%...Believe me all the dividend hunters have it on their screens and marked for $19 a share. But heck who knows......I wonder who they are gonna make as CEO. That will be the tell.

Topic.Title: Finally A very good reason for Apple to consider Nvidia

Message.Msg: You don't think Apple could put together a 1.9 GHz quad-core A6 at 28nm too if it wanted to ? Apple chooses its sku designs carefully to ensure maximum battery life. When it wants real performance it sticks Intel cpus into its Macs etc. That Geekbench score is about as relevant going forward as that estimated Tegra 3 Coremark comparison against an old Core 2 Duo with slugged compile options was i.e. not very.

Topic.Title: Finally A very good reason for Apple to consider Nvidia

Message.Msg: Come on Marsavian you are saying benchmarks aren't important? Us old folks remember How Intel destroyed AMD using benchmarks. You guys built the compiler and AMD was stupid enough not to look at how it was done until it was too late. It gave a 20% advantage to Intel CPUs. It even came out in the New York State Lawsuit and you guys settled. Heck I would and so would have any other company done the same. Poor AMD got what they deserved because they didn't want to investigate until it was too late. But alas we now have an OPEN SOURCE benchmark not controlled by any company and applicable across all processors and all operating systems. Now you say it's not fair using benchmarks for performance comparisons. To me that's like calling the Kettle Black..... Note: Next week Intel will be hit with the Power comparisons and I'm sure they will say those don't mean anything too. LOL

Topic.Title: Finally A very good reason for Apple to consider Nvidia

Message.Msg: Sure benchmarks are important even for a mobile processor but for the latter it has to be in the same battery life ballpark otherwise that will be the issue which is why everyone tends to focus on Surface Pro's battery life rather than its much better than ARM performance. Tegra 4 will not be immune for the same criticism if it does not come up to scratch in battery life in common usage. A6X doubles A5X performance but at the same battery life which is why Apple has stuck to dual-cores for a while now. It may go to quad-core at 28nm or more likely 20nm but it will be a balanced design whatever it chooses. We have to see Tegra 4 in both a production tablet and phone to see how competitive it will be in practice. Until then all these current benchmarks are only really telling you what Project Shield will be like as it won't be clock/thermally throttled either.

Topic.Title: Finally A very good reason for Apple to consider Nvidia

Message.Msg: Well Marsavian as they in Congress We have a framework for agreement. That's good! But I must point out that the benchmarks were done with the Reference tablet....not the Project Shield. Heck I expect Project Shield to be considerably better! With that said I agree that GeekBench2 is the benchmark to use and we need to test it in the first tablet or smartphone that appears. My goodness who would have thought that an ARM processor would challenge an X86 processor on performance and Intel would say that sure...but we need to see the power usage? We truly live in an upside down world. Good Luck with your new CEO

Topic.Title: Finally A very good reason for Apple to consider Nvidia

Message.Msg: 'My goodness who would have thought that an ARM processor would challenge an X86 processor on performance and Intel would say that sure...but we need to see the power usage?' Neither is true except in your rather vivid imagination. Any Ivy Bridge Core over 1 Ghz will beat a 1.9 GHz A15 in single thread performance and the new 10W Y Ivy Bridges start at 1 GHz. I was talking about the Tegra 4's performance in relation to other ARMs and Atom not Core. 'With that said I agree that GeekBench2 is the benchmark to use' Geekbench2 is an overall platform benchmark that tests many things. Even the actual cpu performance tests result totals, which are divided into integer and floating point, are an average of the single-thread and multi-thread tests. If you really want to use it just be aware of it really is which is an amalgamation of many tests like cpu, memory, I-O etc.
